context: [2] They prepared a much purer urea in 1808 when the sparingly soluble urea nitrate was neutralized by aqueous potassium carbonate. [3] After evaporation to dryness, the residue was extracted with alcohol to separate the urea from the potassium nitrate. [4] Evaporation of the alcoholic solution yielded crystals of urea. [5] Because an aqueous solution of urea decomposes on boiling to carbonic acid, acetic acid, and ammonia, they speculated that ammonia-containing calculi might be formed by the partial fermentation of urea in the bladder. [1] Finally in 1817, a pure urea product was isolated, its properties, appearance, and chemical reactions were described, and its analysis was accurately determined by William Prout (first exhibited, he said, at some lectures he had given 3 years earlier). [2] Prout introduced a purification step with animal charcoal before extraction with boiling alcohol. [3] This became the textbook method of choice for the preparation of urea.
